1054535394463645696.text: Here are the numbers as of 8:50 p.m. The mood has improved slightly here at Chernushenko’s party, but still quiet.pic.twitter.com/ZlV4DUMxGJ

1054530582770675713.text: Here’s where we stand in Capital Ward as of about 8:30. Chernushenko camp saying it’s still early. #Ottawapic.twitter.com/deU7jod2uO

1054528621295988737.text: Chernushenko and supporters watch as the very early results come in. So far Anthony Carricato has a very, very slim lead in Capital Ward. #Ottawapic.twitter.com/EQKJdW9Ac1

1054519598916132864.text: I’m at @chernushenko ‘s post-election party at Patty’s Pub in the Glebe. He’s facing four challengers in Capital Ward. For the moment it’s just the incumbent having dinner with supporters. Results coming in about 20 mins #Ottawa #Ottawavotespic.twitter.com/Y4jsdVv0qH

1050785576813658113.text: Candidates talk solutions to Ottawa gun violence in Gloucester-Southgate debate https://www.ottawamatters.com/ottawavotes/candidates-debate-solutions-to-ottawa-gun-violence-in-gloucester-southgate-debate-1081846 … via @ottawamatters #Ottawa #OttNews

1050542637252374529.text: Now we're on to closing statements, debate wrapping up. Thanks for tuning in!

1050542282338779137.text: Soucy: The numbers are clear, there isn't enough money for policing. What is being done isn't effective. City council needs to work together to fix the issue, look past funding. Last 8 years hasn't been addressed properly.

1050541788379807744.text: Golijanin: Crime is affecting some demographics more than others. Frontline officers need to be a bigger part of the budget consultation, despite what "police brass" say. "We're one stray bullet away from someone losing a loved one."

1050541291652542464.text:
Last question: How much specifically will you ask for for crime prevention? 
Deans: Says she has asked for funding for all kinds of groups, voted against police budget to voice anger at lack of funding. Everyone wants to be safe where they live.

1050540013622984704.text:
Next question: What is you biggest issue in the community? 
Soucy: Safety. Funding for first responders. 
Deans: Too many things involved in a community. Says she knows who has the answers people need. 
Golijanin: Access to weed. Need to focus on fighting organized crime.

1050538563698274304.text: Soucy: Bad roads are an example of tax dollars being ill-spent. Need to compensate for bad winters, use proper materials to build it the first time.

1050538227189276672.text:
Next question: Will you improve road conditions? 
Deans: Yes. There's a $70M infrastructure renewal funding gap. Things need to be repaired in a timely fashion. 
Golijanin: Roads were not built to last, need to treat every year like an election year for results.

1050537189870690306.text: Golijanin: Believes in AirBnb regulation, have to keep the free market open. Buyers from over-seas an issue.

1050536833778503680.text:
Next question: What will you do about problem of student housing? 
Soucy: Can't have another Sandy Hill, work with universities to provide housing. Proper oversight short-term rental. 
Deans: Student housing only problematic when disruptive. Stronger bylaws on landlord licesnging

1050535446940332033.text: Deans: Can't keep low-performing routes, have to make sure new routes are financially feasible.

1050534724769181696.text:
Next question: What will you do for transit post LRT launch? 
Golijanin: Transit connectivity is down, will support more routes across the ward. 
Soucy: Has heard that there aren't enough bus stops. OC Transpo should apply resources it already has.

1050533527131807744.text: Soucy: Citizens aren't getting a proper return on their tax investment. City needs to address councilors' budgets, spending on ads.

1050533067436093440.text:
Next question: How will you pay for everything? 
Deans: Says she was supported affordable tax increases. Public expects efficiencies, value. 
Golijanin: Says councilors have spent $10 million on parking, efficiency first property tax second. Won't allow "terrible deals."

1050532379037585408.text: Golijanin: Driving is a privilege, city should review speeding. Road safety is a huge concern, "petty politics" won't get in the way of safety.

1050531989558706177.text:
Next question: What would you do to make infrastructure better in disaster (tornado) situations? 
Soucy: Need to work with all levels of government to improve infra. City wasn't prepared. 
Deans: Climate is changing and City needs debrief on aftermath.

1050530808656617472.text:
Next question: Where do you stand on safe injection sites? 
Golijanin: Supports funding the sites, can't give up on people. 
Deans: Puts her trust in health professionals, sites are step to recovery. 
Soucy: It's controversial but it works. System not perfect.

1050529381355991040.text: Golijanin: Crime affects certain demographics more than others. City hall can't facilitate the convo. More officers solve the problem.

1050528943650955264.text:
Next question: What will you do to stop gun violence in ward? 
Deans: It's troubling, says she's advocated for more police here. Return to community policing, prevention and resilient communities. 
Soucy: City's strategy not working, too reactive. Wants to start youth council.

1050527675159203841.text:
Fifth question: Are you in support of a women's bureau? 
Golijanin: Yes. Says he respects diversity, supports grass-roots movements. 
Deans: Proposed the women's bureau in the first place. Ottawa needs to be a leader. 
Soucy: Also supports it. Need to empower women in politics.

1050526242032635904.text:
Fourth question: Thoughts on providing free transit for homeless people? 
Soucy: Just an idea, need to talk to other municipalities with program already. 
Deans: City has housing first policy.
Golijanin: Shelter use is up, can't give up on people.

1050525093997072385.text:
Third question: What will they do about proposed nuclear dump on Ottawa River? 
Soucy: It's a travesty, will work to avoid placement of the centre. 
Golijanin: Nuclear facilities need to go elsewhere. 
Deans: Not a reasonable placement for waste facility, needs to be debated.

1050523955247759360.text:
Second question: Resident can't use transit because of her disabled child. How will candidate help her child? 
Deans: Complex issue, Para-Transpo available, but has to be worked on.
Soucy: City needs to look at things on more case-by-case basis. 
Golijanin: Going to get it done.

1050522771745206272.text: Deans: Not every member of council is committed to these issues, but says she is. Deans says the councillor won't get far without the passion of the community behind her.

1050522549468061696.text: Soucy: Says he work on the Hill, can't come to everything and isn't paid to. Says he's an emergency medical responder and cares for the community at a medical level.

1050522280197931009.text: Now on to questions from the audience. First one is why didn't Golijanin and Soucy come to city's budget consultation? Golijanin: I've been at seminars, educational workshops. Says he's educated and can't come to everything.

1050521084481552385.text: Deans: Says she was instrumental in getting the EquiPass started, she voted to freeze fares during LRT construction. Says she got extra $2.5 million for affordable housing and it's something every person should be able to have. Access to city services should be barrier-free.

1050519899028709378.text: Golijanin: Affordable housing will be solved through policy like inclusionary zoning. The current 10 year plan on affordable housing is disappointing. Transit isn't affordable either, equipass is a good start, not a good finish.

1050518842621943808.text: Soucy: Transit is too expensive, Ottawa should learn from other cities like Edmonton and Montreal with cheaper bus passes. The city needs more inclusionary zoning, citizens have a right to access services like camps and transit. Francophones need access too.

1050518446419496961.text:
Candidates start by giving their stance on transit, inclusivity, affordable housing, and access to services. 
 #Ottawa #OttNews #OttPoli

1050516147873837056.text: Here are the candidates for Ward 10. Perry Sabourin and Robert Swaita are absent.pic.twitter.com/2SnvOp9XBN

1050514206284345344.text: Good turnout for the Gloucester-Southgate debate tonight, there was one yesterday in the ward too.pic.twitter.com/75VuinhSDD

1050511613013282816.text: Someone near the Greenboro Library is making a statement with their WiFi.pic.twitter.com/tvE2eEXM2z

1050510610931245056.text: Alright more candidates are arriving, looks like we’ll have a debate after all. #Ottawa #ottnews

1050509461691887616.text: 20 people or so in the room now, organizers are here too getting set up, but still no Gloucester Southgate candidates. Apparently the debate actually starts at 630, not 6.

1050506180995379200.text: I’m at the Greensboro Public Library in Gloucester-Southgate for tonight’s municipal election debate. So far there are around 15 people to watch, but I don’t see any candidates yet....

1050029667724324866.text: Ottawa's Really Horrible Enterprises bringing life to homemade food and drinks https://www.ottawamatters.com/midweek-mugging/ottawas-really-horrible-enterprises-bringing-life-to-homemade-food-and-drinks-1077825 … via @ottawamatters

1048010111333978112.text: Last question is about bike lane snow removal. Lowe says the MacArthur bike lane is badly designed, sidewalks should be plowed too. Harris says he doesn't know if the Macarthur bike lane is plowed in the winter.

1048008934554886145.text: Harris says Ottawa community housing has to up standards for seniors' housing, need a safety and security task force for seniors, calls them a treasure to the community.

1048008759862210560.text: Question about quality of life for seniors. Fleury says it's important to improve the programs that already exist. Lowe says accessibility and free transportation is a great place to start.

1048004763055415297.text: Harris says he agree and it should have been done years ago. The community needs to be inclusive and its an "absolute priority."

1048004599892795392.text: Question now about whether the candidates support a women's bureau at city hall. Lowe says he completely supports it and the city doesn't have equal gender representation. Fleury says he's proud of voting for the bureau, city employees must represent diversity of the city.

1048003250878726146.text: Question about ranked voting: Harris and Fleury said yes they support bringing it in. Fleury and Lowe said they also want more diverse people running for council.

1048000626293059584.text: On a question about improving Ottawa for francophones, Harris says Watson is indifferent to francohone concerns. Says he will fight for francophones everyday.

1047998695197659136.text: "When we see landlords leaving their properties abandoned, we cannot allow that to happen, we cannot allow that to happen," Fleury said. Supports protecting the Prime Minister's row.

1047998347900936193.text: Question about heritage protection education initiatives. Harris proposes creating a pamphlet to show the heritage of the ward, says he supports a derelict homes fund. Lowe says he totally supports protecting heritage in the ward and not destroying what's near and dear.

1047996555549011969.text: Fleury says the issue needs to be on the table for discussion, it's very important and has an impact on us. Chalk River is continuing risk. Harris advocates using the community to stop the facility, views stewardship of the land as a crucial duty.

1047996172579692544.text: Next question is about opposing nuclear waste facilities beside the Ottawa River. Lowe says he knows "how nasty this stuff can be in real life," says the plan to build the facility needs to be stopped.

1047995787144122368.text: Lowe says more transparency is needed, Vanier isn't included in Mayor Jim Watson's agenda. Someone yelled "That's why I voted for Clive Doucet" from the back.

1047995551889801216.text: Fleury says in French that he has been opposed to the Salvation Army shelter from the beginning, which drew boos and comments from audience. Says he will give money to SOS Vanier.

1047995176105402368.text: Next question from the audience is about whether the councillor should inform as soon as possible when a planning file will involve the ward. Harris says it's crucial to have an immediate consultation, be transparent and responsible.

1047993929696665600.text: Now on to questions from the floor, instantly a huge line forms. #RideauVanierVotepic.twitter.com/oEqyGyiR2A

1047993601370742784.text: Harris (sorry, not Thierry, that's my bad) rebuts to says he's strictly with communities when it comes to communities vs developers.

1047993305487695872.text: Lowe says heritage needs to be protected, but not at the expense of student housing. Fleury says basically the same about protected student housing. Wants to dedicate more resources to bylaw officers to achieve objectives on property development.

1047992929413869568.text: Thierry says the neighbourhood is historically significant, need to protect it. Says landlords should be licensed, "wouldn't it be nice" if community development plans were respected?

1047992590841176064.text: Final question from community associations: What would you do to support pledge (if you signed it) to support human scale development, diverse development in the ward?

1047991059232436224.text: Thierry says the city should clear sidewalks before roads in the winter and the city lacks complete bike paths. Says the bridge vs tunnel debate for trucks in the ward is politics at its worse.

1047990738162659329.text: Next question is about traffic calming. Fleury starts by saying he wants to lower the speed limit to 30 km/h in residential areas and narrow streets. Lowe it's like a raceway out there, calls for more speed enforcement.

1047990230924414977.text: Fleury says the city has to do planning and take action on the environment today. He says the city has to protect green space in any new development. Calls for open data on cut down trees. Lowe waves one of his rebuttal card to agree with Fleury.

1047989746582999041.text: Next question is about protecting trees. Thierry says the city has to do better on protecting trees, says the meaning of life is about protecting trees. Lowe says Vanier has a nice tree canopy and supports any effort to green the community.

1047989149783838720.text: Lowe says everyone wants to get people off the street, calls the cost of transportation "outrageous."

1047988971857371136.text: Next question is about whether candidates support a 25% mandate for affordable housing in new development. Fleury says "absolutely" (in french), and units targeted for affordability is important. Thierry says the city needs to be for everyone, says housing is a human right.

1047988423196172288.text: Fleury says predictability is important, is in favour of maintaning the 2% yearly tax increase. He says though he's in favour of special levies that are "targeted investments" for specific issues like transit or housing.

1047988036808597504.text: First question about raising taxes in the face of growing city problems. Thierry Harris says the city has an affordable housing crisis and the city has to take a look at transparency with spending. Says the ward "didn't see a nickle" of the city's $10 million surplus last year.

1047986827670446081.text: It's a packed house, I'm estimating more than 100 people are here. Candidates will take pre-written questions, then questions from the floor. Each candidate has three rebuttal cards, something I haven't seen at these ward debates so far. #rideauvaniervote

1047986090366230529.text: I’m in Rideau-Vanier Ward this evening for the all-candidates debate. Incumbent Mathieu Fleury has three challengers, two of who are attending. #Ottawa #OttNews #OttCitypic.twitter.com/VNiC2xOAVI

1046575148453715969.text: The debate is now over, don't forget to vote on Oct. 22.

1046560238445502464.text: Mangone closes by saying he met a 10-year-old boy who helped out with tornado relief and handing out water. Says he personally helped out by carrying water and with communication. He said Egli also doesn't spend enough money from his ward budget, is 7th from the bottom.

1046559203488395264.text: Arshinoff thanks community association presidents for their work on tornado cleanup, says he will work on youth recreation programs and giving young people something to do. Also commuting to Bayshore on transit is too hard, need to focus on more tailored solutions.

1046558491782139904.text: Dean says his big issue is the city's debt and spending is "way off" from the priorities. Core services need more attention, then frills. Cites Maslow's hierarchy of needs as a spending model. Nepean has a surplus before amalgamation, debt-free is much better.

1046557918164914176.text: Weber says it's time to hold council and the mayor accountable, and institute term limits. He wants a complete overhaul of city government with online voting and lower voting age. "Let's make Ottawa a safer place to be, not a nannie state."

1046557380564193280.text: Now on to closing remarks. Egli says he won't spend residents' money needlessly and takes money seriously. In terms of debt, the city isn't anywhere near its caps and money needs to be borrowed. He also says lessons will be learned from the recent tornados.

1046555312512270336.text: Egli says he voted against removing full council meeting minutes and wants to get more information out to community members. Arshinoff says engagement is hard without debate, which isn't happening with Jim Watson as mayor. Says city staff are inaccessible to the public.

1046554855777742849.text: Weber says he would be infavour of lowering the voting age so more young people can get involved. Mangone says local leaders need to be involved in all levels of government.

1046554438993948673.text: Next question is about improving civic governance and engagement. Dean says Egli isn't transparent enough with how he's voted on issues and more needs to be online. Also wants community centres more involved with governance.

1046553968552398849.text: Mangone says the city needs more private long-term care facilities and public-private partnerships. Weber says facilities could be moved outside the city to where it's cheaper to run them.

1046553603803156480.text: Egli says the city is looking at the butterfly model for long-term care and the city is aware of the current issues. Says he will also enhance outreach to seniors if reelected.

1046553296889155586.text: Dean says services are being cut across the board and it's a problem that seniors' homes are getting little attention, he says.

1046553012322410497.text: Next question is about changes to long-term care and any changes the city should make to it. Ashinoff says the homes are a problem across the province and he says he's worried that it seems like ones run by the government often have issues.

1046551337285103616.text: Dean says the volunteers on the ground did a great job, but management could have been better prepared.

1046551049346187264.text: Arshinoff says the priority was making sure everybody was safe and had power. The blocked entrances were about making sure emergency vehicles could get through. "Sometimes you have to be inconvenienced for good services."

1046550663768027136.text: Next question is about the aftermath of the tornado and the blocked entrance/exits to neighbourhoods. Egli says people just out to look present a safety issue and the city will learn a lot in the next weeks and months. He says the police had a tough time making people safe.

1046548890739191813.text: Mangone says he used to take one bus to work at the government. He wants to lower the cost of bussing by 50 cents, which will increase demand. Weber says OC Transpo needs to be fast and cheap.

1046548392007159808.text: Egli says the LRT will get buses out of the core, which makes neighbourhood service more efficient. Equitable passes put more people on the buses and ridership is up slightly.

1046548170963144705.text: Dean says the quality of transit is "plummeting," which is because of LRT construction. He wants to make it more accessible. Also says the city's debt is a big problem.

1046547881921064960.text: Arshinoff says transit is good if you're going downtown and back, but not otherwise. "It's transfer after transfer after transfer," he said. Says the city isn't putting enough work into the current system.

1046547473001533441.text: Egli says money does flow to the city, but the city is the "small partner" in it.

1046547228125548544.text: Dean says the city pays for security at parades and protests. The current pay structure doesn't work, he said. Weber says the city should live within our means.

1046546906279809026.text: Now on to audience questions. The first one is about transfer payments on property values. Mangone says he will do more research. Arshinoff says the city needs to benefit more from the services provided to the federal government.

1046546460953718784.text: Mangone wants more roundabouts, which he says will save on electricity costs to operate traffic lights.

1046546227272318982.text: Dean says the ward has three of the top 10 most dangerous intersections in the city. He wants more photo radar and "anything" to slow people down. Says Merivale needs to be good for everyone.

1046545916247896064.text: Arshinoff says the road is a "trying issue" and the constant development makes it worse. He proposes a carpool lane and more bus lanes on the road. Weber says "it is what it is" and traffic won't be fixed.

1046545515985473536.text: Next question is about traffic and getting it moving on Merivale Road. Egli says what would fix it is to rebuild it, but that won't happen. Says he's working to create a more friendly streetscape and ways to get people off the roads.

1046544231366561792.text: Next question is about the people the candidates have met in the ward.

1046544061061091329.text: Arshinoff proposes creating a diversity bureau at city hall as a one-stop-shop to help people deal with bureaucracy. He also says staff should be available during non-traditional business hours.

1046543764179873792.text: Egli says the best way to represent diverse communities is to work with the Knoxdale-Merivale council and faith based groups. Says he does outreach at a regular basis.

1046543443789582336.text: Weber says more security cameras need to be installed in "bad neighbourhoods" and more cooperation between police forces. Mangone says more town halls and coffee days in the community need to happen. Says the councillor needs to better communicate with community leaders.

1046543036279377926.text: Second question is about making sure the diverse neighbourhoods in the ward get represented. Dean says the city needs to partner with religious and diverse communities, have more investment in youth.

1046542752815747074.text: Weber says OC Transpo is unreliable and the military should have been brought in to held deal with tornado aftermath.

1046542529884299264.text: Mangone says communications after the tornado relief is an issue. He attacks Egli for not spending enough on traffic calming measures like cross walks and other unused money.

1046542220503986176.text: Egli says tornado relief is the biggest issue facing the ward right now. He says the city needs a plan for relief and reforestation even though it's early days in the aftermath. Says speeding gets moved down to second place.

1046541871911178240.text: Dean agrees that traffic calming is an issue. Also snow removal and the city's debt.

1046541494310633472.text: First question is about the 3 top challenges in Ward 9, and how would they address them? Arshinoff says the top concern is speeding and the city needs better enforcement. Delay of the LRT is also a concern.

1046533906953109504.text: This area of the city was hit hard in the tornados two weeks ago. Lots of trees went down in Craig Henry and damage to people's property. The room is getting full, so we'll see if that comes up as a major issue in the debate.

1046533541390143489.text: I'm in Knoxdale-Merivale tonight's municipal election debate between Keith Egli, Peter Anthony Weber, James Dean, Warren Arshinoff and Luigi Mangone. #Ottawa #OttNews

1043184483711643648.text: Residents call for better and increased affordable housing in Ottawa at Bay Ward debate https://www.ottawamatters.com/ottawavotes/residents-call-for-better-and-increased-affordable-housing-at-bay-ward-debate-1055959 … via @ottawamatters

1042940003976851457.text: Kavanagh said it's always difficult seeing things that won't be used, there's a big problem with diverting things away from landfills. Says she's in favour of banning single-use plastic.

1042939708433588224.text: On recycling, Dransfield said there is a lot that the city could recycle that they could and more needs to be done. Restaurants only recycling 12 per cent, which is a "shame."

1042936881304887296.text: Kavanagh said she's in favour of looking at it.

1042936819279552512.text: Dath says she doesn't know enough about the issue, would need to consult with those most affected. Dransfield says he doesn't know the whole scenario, but would council would probably vote against buying something used with child labour.

1042936014468079617.text: Next question is whether the candidates would support a Boycott Divest and Sanction motion against Israel if it came to council. Robinson said he would serve the interest of the residents of his ward.

1042932102365233152.text: Dransfield says it's probably $20, says he wouldn't pay anyone working for him anything less than a living wage. Kavanagh Stats Canada has good guidelines on poverty and it's not cookie cutter.

1042931692015575040.text: What's a living wage? Dath says she doesn't know, but a minimum wage earner makes around $29k/ year and people are squabbling together an income. Robinson says it's variable because the costs are different everywhere and should always be evaluated.

1042929145980710912.text: Robinson says kids need to be involved in their schools whether or not they're into sports, different options need to be offered in the community. Kavanagh praises teachers for what they're doing after school and wants to see more things offered.

1042928477555445760.text: Dransfield says youth want things to do. Wants to introduce mentorship programs with small businesses to meet the people that could hire them. Dath says recreation facilities are in disrepair, need to gear them towards what people actually want to do.

1042927963287707653.text: Next question is about bored youth getting into gangs. The questioner wants to hear proposals got putting sports centres and art centres in the ward.

1042926400418721792.text: Next question is about accessible housing and supports for people with physical and mental disabilities. Robinson says there is no one-size fits all approach and they need to be wide ranging.

1042924818805321729.text: Dransfield says more rules need to be in place about forcing companies to build more affordable housing. Kavanagh calls it a growing problem that needs to be tackled now. Says the social housing stock is inadequate.

1042924426658930689.text: Next question is about affordable housing and homeless people. What should the city do about providing housing to homeless people? Dath says the city needs to focus on affordable and non-profit housing, calls the system "broken" and the city needs to do more.

1042923584509730816.text: Kavanagh says the LRT routes and stations need to be accessible. "This is something that's really, really important to me. It's a deal-breaker," she says. Robinson says he's very mindful of accessibility issues and sidewalks are an issue. "We need to do more," he says.

1042922931636953088.text: Dath says the city has an accessibility issue and it needs to be corrected. "it has to be the default, not the exception," she says. Dransfield says he would push to make sure all new construction is accessible and that tasers should be subject to strict rules.

1042922445517123584.text: First question is from Heather on accessibility. She says steps are a big problem for her downtown, also cites a lack of affordable accessible housing. Says it's also a problem that all police officers are getting tasers. Asks about position on accessibility and tasers.

1042921768954953728.text: Alright the next part of the debate is to open the floor to questions from people in attendance. There's a good line already forming, should be interesting...

1042921492235735040.text: If I didn't Tweet this before, Marc Lugert isn't in attendance at the debate. Just FYI

1042920326894505986.text: Dath says OC-Transpo should be more selective about advertisers like pay-day lenders on buses.

1042920136879947778.text: Dransfield says banks need to be regulated more, but all you can do at a city level is to stop them from building on every corner. "Extortion systems," shouldn't be allowed in neighbourhoods.

1042919893182500864.text: Kavanagh calls them "horrible", says alternatives, like postal banking, should be offered so low-income people don't get caught in vicious cycles.

1042919630723985408.text: Next topic: Predatory lending. Robinson says there are more pay-day lenders near Lincoln Fields than coffee shops, the city needs to make sure they work for people who don't and don't prey on people.

1042918842639347712.text: Next topic: Infrastructure. Robinson talks about fair wages and says that the best people should be hired for a job. Dransfield says the city shouldn't be bringing in people from out of town on construction projects. He says the city needs to ensure green space in low-income area

1042917743681449985.text: Dath says houses have to have insulation to be efficient, says it's basic human rights to have doors and windows that close.

1042917563322122240.text: Dransfield, who voted no on the question, says he voted no because affordable housing is in such bad quality that it's impossible to save on energy. The solution is to improve the quality of the city's housing.

1042917328009125888.text: Next topic is affordable utilities. ACORN wants to ensure hydro rates are affordable for low-income earners and the city should reward people who save energy. Kavanagh says everyone benefits from saving energy.

1042915705794912256.text: Next topic is transit. Robinson says that beyond affordability it needs to work. Says there have been a lot of failures in transit over the past weeks. Para-Transpo causes added stress to people. Presto is a "no-brainer", shouldn't be a minimum on adding money.

1042915182333255680.text: Dath says childcare shouldn't be a luxury, have to move subsidies along with the child.

1042914960546791424.text: Dransfield says it's not fair to make people spend their entire salary on daycare, low income people need to be able to affordable. He answered No to having the province cap costs at $10/day because with the current provincial government it's not feasible.

1042914672674975744.text: Kavanagh calls childcare an economic investment, not a cost. Was "appalled" when the city let the daycare at Bayshore close. She says all levels of government have failed on childcare, wants to make it "completely affordable."

1042914390016647168.text: Next topic is on child care. ACORN wants the province to cap daycare costs at $10/ day. Robinson says we can always do better on childcare. He says he wants to makes sure the province can't download childcare costs onto the city.

1042913861324529664.text: Dransfield says affordable housing won't raise taxes. The rules need to be put in place and are necessary, can't just kick people out of housing. Dath says affordable housing is a small step and a small bandaid for the issue, says she wants $12 million in housing from the city.

1042913468930613248.text: Kavanagh says she would put requirements to include affordable housing in the Lincoln Fields redevelopment. "We have to have affordable housing for our community. This is not just about getting high rents, it's about including everyone."

1042912999931994112.text: Next question is on housing, the platform points get applause from the audience. "We need to do more to help residents access the services they need," Robinson says. "We need to be mindful there are only finite resources available." Says there needs to be a balance, not raise tax

1042912258320265218.text: Kavanagh says the city should go door-to-door to find eligible voters in areas where people move around a lot, including to register the homeless to vote. Dransfield says door-to-door registry might help in some situations, but it's not the only fix to registering people to vote

1042911537327792128.text: Same issue, Dransfield says polling places should be adjusted for each municipal election depending on where the voters are. Dath largely agrees, says data should be used to place voting places.

1042910944840409088.text: On reducing barriers to voting, Robinson says he wants to look at online voting for people who don't want to - or can't- leave their houses. Kavanagh says the city has to ensure there are enough staff at polls to keep things moving so people have a positive experience.

1042909950823952384.text: Robinson says he thinks all voters should have reasonable access to polling stations. Kavanagh says advanced polling stations are part of education- people will think about voting on the actual election day if they see the advanced polls advertised.

1042909134738227201.text: Now candidates are going to have 1 min to answer how they would support ACORN's Agenda for Change. The first question is about democratic rights.

1042908837651468288.text: Kavanagh says affordable housing is really important and should be a priority at city hall. She says she plans to make transportation costs an important issue as well.

1042908287182635008.text: Dath says she's not accepting donations for her campaign, which makes her beholden to nobody except the residents of the ward.

1042906593015152640.text: The debate tonight is focused on ACORN's Agenda for Change, which has the goal to "build a base of progressive voters in strategic wards." It focuses on issues like housing, transit, anti-predatory lending, and affordable housing

1042902948383092736.text: I'll be live Tweeting the debate tonight, same as last time in Osgoode Ward, but aiming for quality over quantity. Development is a big issue in the ward, so is the new LRT line, and traffic. Debate starts in about 15 mins.

1042902609944698881.text: I'm in Bay Ward tonight at the Britannia United Church for the municipal debate hosted by ACORN Ottawa. The Candidates are Trevor Robinson, Marc Lugert, Theresa Kavanagh, Don Dransfield and Erica Dath. Incumbent Mark Taylor isn't running for re-election. #Ottawa

1042490991951806464.text: What a way to absolutely crush my beautiful Wednesday afternoon....https://twitter.com/SanJoseSharks/status/1042466178877153280 …

1042490123764424704.text: Mickle Macks Haberdashery looking to fill Ottawa's specialty hat void https://www.ottawamatters.com/midweek-mugging/mickle-macks-haberdashery-looking-to-fill-ottawas-specialty-hat-void-1051980 … via @ottawamatters

1040402885039742976.text: That's the end of the debate. I'm signing off.

1040402157415981056.text: Banfalvi says he wants to save money at city hall. "There's a lot of money going out of Osgoode and I don't know how much is coming in," he said. Brings up donating part of his salary to Project Osgoode, "I don't need that much money." Argues again for traffic cameras.

1040401453301391360.text: Darouze starts by thanking people for coming. "Yes, we did have a storm water fee, it was justifiable," he said. Says all his promises have been kept and efficiencies were found. Promises that taxes won't be raised more than people can afford.

1040400857987145728.text: Scharfe says Osgoode was forced into amalgamation in 2000, calls the green bin a multi-million dollar waste, will cancel the storm water tax. "George has been in one term, he's raised your taxes and given you a tax you don't deserve."

1040400444915310592.text: Sheldrick says she likes the lifestyle in the ward, "this is home, this is not the hustle and bustle." "We don't want to have the city come out and tel us what to do, we want to keep our rural life," she said. Says she wants to help seniors stay at home.

1040399953057656833.text: Now on to closing statements. Tysick says he's running for his family, he doesn't like the trend the city is going in. Brings up debt, "If we think we're losing services now, what's going to happen when interest rates go up?... there's so much wrong that we need to address"

1040399466325405696.text: Banfalvi says that while Darouze wanted to keep the police budget increase at 2 per cent per year, it was 5 per cent last year. Says the increase shouldn't be capped at 2 per cent.

1040399263258144769.text: Darouze said city council doesn't interfere with the police budget, the police need to be more efficient with how they operate. He says now Osgoode has own police officers dedicated to the ward.

1040398972634857472.text: Scharfe says the community and kids need to trust the police, the Osgoode police centre should never have been closed, says he will get it back.

1040398783262019585.text: Sheldrick says she would fight to bring back community police office. "We need to bring someone back here," she said.

1040398567196700672.text: Tysick says rural police services are being cut in favour of downtown, the police budget needs to be raised by more than 2 per cent, "let them ask for what they need to keep us safe."

1040398264875405312.text: Next question: The community police office is in Orleans, but Osgoode needs one. Will they get one?

1040396839546056705.text: Banfalvi says it's simplistic to vilify the mayor, can't always fight the mayor, need a balance.

1040396683052408832.text: Darouze says rural and urban residents have different issues, have to work with the mayor to get things done for the community. 'Everything we asked, we got."

1040396338058297345.text: Next: Will you always agree with the mayor and always submit to his issues? Tysick says no, has worked against things that the mayor wants. Sheldrick says "odds are no" that she would always agree with the mayor.

1040396011707875329.text: Banfalvi says people have to ask whether they're happy with what Darouze has done. As a councillor you have to take the ward's representation to city hall, make relationships for the future.

1040395749979127808.text: Darouze says he has shown he can negotiate to get better outcomes for his community.

1040395673105887236.text: "If you don't vote for someone like myself you're going to pay," Scharfe says with regards to the green bin program.

1040395415227555840.text: Tysick says he won't vote with the mayor, but won't be a contrarian. Will always seek feedback. Sheldrick says the ward is her home, will fight for the people living there, they come first.

1040395031771701249.text: Next: Will you represent Osgoode at council, or council in Osgoode?

1040394925316009984.text: Tysick says he grew up in a rural area, understands the issues. "People care about your involvement in the community, not your postal code... that's what it comes down to." "What's a few hundred meters?"

1040394685578063874.text: Banfalvi says Tysick doesn't live in the ward either. "I think I can bring an unbiased mind to the ward," Banfalvi says.

1040394408892391424.text: Next question: Why are you running in this ward, you don't live here?

1040394338411270145.text: Banfalvi attacks Darouze for voting for storm water tax when he said he wouldn't, but says Darouze negotiated a good deal. The city subsidizes the cost of fixing the culverts, residents pay 1/6th- 1/8th of the real price.

1040394002028064768.text: Scharfe says "forget it, we're not buying it." Darouze says the issue isn't with the ditch in-front of your house, it's about the major culverts. Says urban people won't pay for rural infrastructure.

1040393647018041344.text: Sheldrick also says no, she's had drainage issues but they haven't been fixed, she has done the work herself.

1040393513496567813.text: Next question about the storm water tax: do you think it's fair to pay the tax if you're on your own well and septic? Tysick: No.

1040392930551246849.text: "Our problem in rural Ottawa is not only the rate, it's the delivery charges," Darouze said. He says Osgoode Ward is listed as mid-density, when it's actually full-density.

1040392701294698496.text: Scharfe says he would force the provincial government to change them to Hydro Ottawa.

1040392406221381632.text: Tysick says Hydro One won't end over charging by 30 per cent to people, Sheldrick says it's a provincial concern, have to have faith in the provincial government to change it.

1040392054172409857.text: Next question to everyone: Before 2014 voters were told hydro costs would be lowered south of Mitch Owens Road, why hasn't equalization occured?

1040391832130052096.text: Sheldrick says she supports red light cameras.

1040391608221544448.text: "We have to look to the future guys," Banfalvi says in support of traffic cameras. Tysick says police officers are better, a camera just sends bills.

1040391337101729793.text: Next Q to Darouze: How many red light cameras are in Osgoode ward? Darouze says "None." Scharfe disputes this, says there is a camera on Leitrim road. Darouze says this camera isn't in the ward.

1040391025779367936.text: Banfalvi says Darouze voted against 5 per cent police budget increase, has solutions for police problems. Wants to put up traffic cameras because he admits he went 40 over the limit on the way over here.

1040390689387769856.text: Darouze says 50 new paramedics were hired since he was elected, the ambulance response time in 2017 was 11:46, which has gotten better. Will keep hiring up with population growth.

1040390191972667392.text: Scharfe says there aren't that many calls to police in Osgoode, as compared to Vanier, will demand Leitrim Station is permanently open.

1040389919133229056.text: Sheldrick says the problem is about how patients are transferred. There needs to be a nurse on staff at hospitals to register ambulance patients. Yes, there need to be more police in Osgoode, but people need to actually call them.

1040389659153457152.text: Tysick says generally half of all ambulances are on the road, this needs to be fixed. Sometimes it takes an hour for an ambulance to arrive.

1040389362788134912.text: Next question: Why were there 256 times when no ambulances were available, Why are there no police in Osgoode?

1040388959984082949.text: Tysick said he would get a youth council going. "If you don't get [kids] something positive to do, they're going to do something negative." Says he wants to get youth programs going at community centres.

1040388730417102848.text: "I would be fully willing to support OYA," Sheldrick said. Says she likes the program that works with seniors. "It takes a community to raise a family," she said.

1040388347716358144.text: Darouze said he saved the Osgoode Youth Association, which kept the youth engaged. The association is a model for the city, he said, and is something he's engaged in.

1040388085295378432.text: Banfalvi says he grew up in a poor neighbourhood, after school programs help keep kids from "stupid" things.

1040387892294680577.text: Next question: How does your platform support the youth of the ward?

1040387778402410497.text: "It comes down to pragmatism," Tysick says. He says building relationships is important. "If you want to be effective you have to build good relationships with those people around the table."

1040387473770131456.text: Sheldrick says she's tired of puppet councillors that always vote with the mayor, you have to stand up for the ward.

1040387294375497728.text: Scharfe says his platform puts the ward's people in charge, the councillor is the messenger for the people.

1040387121847033856.text: "You cannot win every fight, you have to pick your battle," Darouze says the councillors have to work together.

1040386866825109505.text: All candidates are asked how they will advance Osgoode's interests in a council with 23 councillors? Banfalvi says he's in favour of reducing the number of councillors, like in Toronto. Also in favour of putting diapers in green bin.

1040386535869169664.text: Darouze is asked why Mitch Owens Road isn't painted with lines yet? He says the city has to do it, the city is behind with paving and only has one painting truck.

1040386321162752000.text: Tysick says the candidate's plans are more important than the postal code.

1040386250887385088.text: Next question is for Tysick: Is it not necessary for the councillor to live in the ward they represent?

1040386064576335872.text: "Absolutely we all want clean air and water," Tysick says. He said the Spring Hill landfill is a mess, wants to implement a waste to energy program.

1040385764255834113.text: Sheldrick says she wants to expand the green bin program, "We're paying for it anyways, let's use it properly." Wants to also expand recycling, plant more fruit trees.

1040385494322802688.text: Scharfe says he wants to cancel sewage spreading on farm land. "We have bylaws against dumpling anti-freeze down the sewer but I can tell you people do it all the time." "As a farmer I can't do anything that harms the land."

1040385167062433793.text: Darouze says farmers are interested in protecting the environment. "We are always looking at our emissions," he says about city planning.

1040384873716801536.text: "Every decision I would make would consider the environment," Banfalvi says. 'It wouldn't be my top priority but I do think it's important." He said although residents don't like the green bin, he wouldn't end it.

1040384579528323072.text: Now we're on to audience questions: Many platforms call back environmental programs, how will you protect the enviro for farmers, ourselves and future generations?

1040384254977355776.text: "Where George has a 90 per vent rate of voting along with the mayor, I'm going to do what's best for our riding." I'm going to vote for you, that's the biggest issue, he said.

1040384076920893442.text: Banfalvi starts by complementing Darouze on voting for storm water, says otherwise residents would pay $300 each. He asks Tysick how he and Scharfe are different.

1040383779926302721.text: Darouze after amalgamation fees had to be recovered, the fees are for major roads. "For us to be able to fix these roads we need money. We cannot take money from our roads and asphalt." Says the fee was capped, rural roads are prioritized.

1040382963958128640.text: Scharfe to Darouze: Why would you vote for the storm water tax and saddle Osgoode with debt?

1040382792054517760.text: Scharfe says you have to look at credibility, there are similarities between a police officer and a politician. "People ask you to be honest, and be fair." Says people who built the riding deseve to be city hall.

1040382566786772992.text: Sheldrick addresses her question to Scharfe; Do you think it's beneficial for a councillor to be born and raised in the riding they're running in?

1040382410414678016.text: Darouze says he did an audit for the green bin program and a dump, audited OC Transpo. Says $78 million was saved. Tysick quipped back something about the numbers, I couldn't hear what though.

1040381875913601024.text: Tysick asks the first question: How much money has Darouze saved the City of Ottawa?

1040381381153480705.text: "I spent the last two months travelling around this ward," Tysick said. Attacks Darouze on voting for storm water tax. Tysick is also concerned about speeding, wants more police presence in Ottawa's rural wards. "We need more policing, period... lack of protection has got to stop

1040380743401320449.text: Sheldrick says she will "stand up for the little guy", "We are one city, we need to be able to help these people." She says poverty and homelessness is not just an urban issue, but in rural ridings too. "I'm out for the individual people, the humans in this ward," Sheldrick said.

1040380081594482690.text: Scharfe said he will cancel the "ridiculous" green-bin program, end the storm water tax, remove all red light cameras in the ward.

1040379184256827392.text: Darouze says being city councillor isn't easy. There are lots of issues and the city is massive by area. Osgoode is one of the 4 rural wards, says it's a battle to get things done for residents. Darouze touts his record of paving and reconstructing 150 km of roadways.

1040378363184128000.text: Banfalvi starts, he's going to school at U of T and says he brings a fresh perspective. #Ottawa #OttNews

1040378091976187905.text: Candidates will start with a 3 minute opening statement, then the candidates will have a minute to ask another candidate a question, then they'll take audience questions.

1040376355605630976.text: Something interesting, on the back of Banfalvi's pamphlet it says he will donate $100k of his own salary to Project Osgoode if elected. In 2016 Ottawa city councillors made $99,647, so over a 4 year term that's over a quarter of his salary. #Ottawa

1040375339355000832.text: Auguste Banfalvi is here actually, he just handed be a pamphlet.

1040373010354458624.text: Osgoode is a rural riding and one of the biggest by land area in Ottawa. Road maintenance is a major issue in the riding, so are storm water fees. A cannabis grow-op is seeking approval in Metcalfe, so that could be an issue. Debate starts in 10 minutes. #OttNews

848229958770098176.text: The meeting is now over and #RRRA have a redo on their February elections in late April. Thanks for tunining in!

848221210878115840.text: Naqvi and Brobio both vote against the motion, Pollak votes in favour. The motion passes. #RRRA #Carleton

848220638825328640.text: Pollak specifically mention's OPIRG's levy, which students can opt-out of, says he opted out 2 years in a row. #RRRA #Carleton

848220419136114689.text: Pollak says that if a group feels threatened by RRRA posting about opt-outs, the group is limiting what #RRRA can tell constituents.

848220152105775105.text: "This motion is all about giving students an open society," Pollak says. #Carleton #RRRA

848219588093501440.text: Naqvi says the motion might make #RRRA "way too political", RRRA about making sure students are comfortable. #Carleton

848219028313210880.text: Naqvi asks Pollak if Costitutional Review committee has met since last meeting, Pollak says they haven't, but the motion has been improved.

848218173648326656.text: Pollak says the motion is about informing residence students about opt-outs in a fair way, controlling their money. #RRRA #Carleton

848217374650249217.text: One motion on the table: Pollak's motion to have the VP Admin give information to council in a non-biased way. #RRRA #Carleton

848214704187207682.text: VP programming Zophia Brobio says #RRRA will have a detergent drive for next year's students.

848214289647374336.text: Pollak says it's "sad" that this is the last #RRRA meeting. #Carleton

848214002194952192.text: Council chair says the budget doesn't apply to this, council voted to go with Kennelly's report at the last meeting. #RRRA #Carleton

848212736957919237.text: Looks like we're taking a 5 minute break to clear up the budget confusion.

848212479217995780.text: Council doesn't have the information on whether there is money in the budget for the new election. #RRRA #Carleton

848212092478001152.text: One councillor asks for a vote on it since the decision requires an expenditure. #Carleton #RRRA

848211938127609857.text: Pollak says #RRRA saved over $2000 by going online with elections rather than paper. #Carleton

848211720007012354.text: Well folks, looks like election season isn't quite over at #Carleton.

848211474216611840.text: Kennelly says he hopes his decision has wisdom in it. #RRRA #Carleton

848211291483373569.text: "I found the violations were violations and my solutions to this is so you don't get into any more a mess, is to have a revote," #Carleton

848210880772939777.text: Council chair says council doesn't have to approve it today, voted to approve Kennelly's decision last meeting. #RRRA #Carleton

848210524575870977.text: Pollak says there's precedent for this. There was a second election in the last five years. #RRRA #Carleton

848209985846878209.text: #RRRA president Hyder Naqvi says the last date has passed for an election, Kennelly says the circumstances are exceptional. #RRRA #Carleton

848209815625228289.text: Kennelly says he can't control online content. "Go for it."

848209601703141378.text: "I don't want people distracting people since this is exam time." #RRRA #Carleton

848209507155140608.text: Kennelly says he'll take down any posters and fliers since it's exam time. #RRRA #Carleton

848209230196768770.text: Kennelly says all five slates will be on the ballot, the exact same ballot as in Feb. #RRRA #Carleton

848208975883632643.text: The ballots will be the same as in February. #Carleton #RRRA

848208873441906689.text: Kennelly says he will help #RRRA find finances for the new election. #Carleton

848208766730457088.text: There won't be any campaigning, will be all word of mouth. "Your most important role as a candidate is to get the word out."

848208631648702464.text: Kennelly says most people are still here at that time. Says ballot will go to Cmail accounts. Won't be a normal campaign. #RRRA #Carleton

848208462366597120.text: "My solution is the students should decide on who represents them next year," Kennelly says. Calls for a new vote on April 18 and 19. #RRRA

848208188168175616.text: Says candidates need to take responsibility for the rules, the rules have a substantial effect on election process. #RRRA #Carleton

848208056651571201.text: "Basically, a student election needs some rules, I don't know why it's so tough, these rules aren't so tricky," he said. #RRRA #Carleton

848207655973912576.text: "The fact that the slate remained on the ballot raises problems," Kennelly says. #RRRA #Carleton

848207547693752321.text: Kennelly says the CEO and DEO acted judiciously, says they were reasonable in assessments of violations. #RRRA #Carleton

848207284295565312.text: "The Fresh RRRA candidate should never have entered into that conversation," Kennelly says about bribery allegation. CEO was right. #RRRA

848207119862157313.text: Kennelly says CEO was correct on first violation. #RRRA #Carleton

848206981815050240.text: Fresh RRRA's disqualification the night before the election, too late to get them off the ballot, Kennelly said. "It's a weird one." #RRRA

848206773618176000.text: "I'll make this quick," Kennelly says. Has met with CEO and DEO of election, Fresh RRRA execs. #RRRA #Carleton

848206434928128001.text: Kennelly about to give his report, #RRRA VP Admin Daniel Pollak thanks him for "unbiased" report. #Carleton

848206004659597312.text: CUSA president Fahd Alhattab motions to have Kennelly's report come first, before anything else. #RRRA #Carleton

848205391955623942.text: We're in St. Pats room 435 if anyone wants to join us. Still waiting to start. #RRRA #Carleton

848205066012119040.text: The meeting in March was to be the last meeting of the year, but after #RRRA voted to have Kennelly decide on Fresh RRRA, this got scheduled

848203209642569728.text: If Kennelly decides not to disqualify Fresh #RRRA, that slate will be the next executive, rather than Next Step who came in 2nd. #Carleton

848202965273935872.text: At the last meeting, council decided to have Kennelly rule on it as a third party, rather than vote on it in #RRRA council.

848202830905315330.text: On the agenda for the #RRRA meeting today, #Carleton Ombudsperson Jim Kennelly will be giving his decision on Fresh RRRA's disqualification.

848202609664163840.text: I will be live-Tweeting the #RRRA meeting today at 12 p.m. Stay tuned. #Carleton

841046818595180544.text: Sorry for the delay, after the revote council voted to have the Ombudsman decide on Fresh RRRA's disqualification. #Carleton #RRRA

841027131635318784.text: Council votes against sending the decision to a third party, they'll decide on it at this meeting. #Carleton #RRRA

841026621779935241.text: Well not yet actually, now council is arguing about whether the Ombudsman plays a role with #RRRA

841026257684987909.text: Council is now voting on whether to send the decision to the Ombudsman, needs a simple majority to pass. #Carleton #RRRA

841023802477797376.text: "In now way am I standing up here and trying to threaten you," May said. She said she's in support of a third party review. #Carleton #RRRA

841023208736337926.text: Brobio says taking the case to court will hurt residence students, appeals are meant to be heard in council. #Carleton #RRRA

841022658812772352.text: Now we're moving into debate on the motion to go to the Ombudsman. #Carleton #RRRA

841021766566850562.text: Alhattab asks if the #RRRA budget has money in it for a lawsuit. #Carleton #RRRA

841021671851085824.text: Naqvi says the Ombudsman would just be another delay in the case, #RRRA has insurance for legal costs. #Carleton

841021343449665536.text: Fresh VP candidate Anthony Hajji said he also thinks a third party would be a good idea #Carleton #RRRA

841020956751585280.text: Both May and Walker say they would be happy with having the Ombudsman make a decision.#Carleton #RRRA

841019999921795077.text: Alhattab suggests that Fresh RRRA say in writing that they will not pursue litigation after the possible decision of the third party #RRRA

841019630378442752.text: The third party in this case would be the University Ombudsman, Jim Kennelly. #Carleton #RRRA

841019276064628737.text: Now there's a motion on the table to send the matter to a third party to review it. #Carleton #RRRA

841018639553835008.text: Now voting on motion to table to another council meeting. #Carleton #RRRA

841018495638884353.text: Alhattab says having a third person to review the matter is the best option, cites his own experience and possible lawsuit. #Carleton #RRRA

841017553136803840.text: Walker says council should just push through and get it done this meeting. #Carleton #RRRA

841017394667610113.text: Ok now we're going into debate. One councillor just motioned to table it, about to vote. #Carleton #RRRA

841016975165968385.text: We were on a break for the last 10 minutes trying to get the CEO to send in evidence from last year, but she couldn't, so we're back to Qs

841011941493657601.text: ... and that's the reason for inconsistencies. #Carleton #RRRA

841011790557384705.text: Walker says she might have been harder on violations this year than last year. #Carleton #RRRA
